--- title: "In-class Exercise 9" author: "kai feng" date: "Oct 21, 2024" date-modified: "last-modified" execute: eval: true echo: true freeze: true --- # 1.0 Setup ### 1.1 Installing R-Packages ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pacman::p_load(spdep, sp, tmap, sf, ClustGeo, cluster, factoextra, NbClust, tidyverse, GGally) ``` ::: ### 1.2 Importing Shan data ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} shan_sf <- read_rds("data/rds/shan_sf.rds") shan_ict <- read_rds("data/rds/shan_ict.rds") shan_sf_cluster <- read_rds("data/rds/shan_sf_cluster.rds") ``` :::

# 2.0 Conventional Hierarchical Clustering ::: panel-tabset ## Step 1: Hierarchical Clustering ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} proxmat <- dist(shan_ict, method = 'euclidean') hclust_ward <- hclust(proxmat, method = 'ward.D') groups <- as.factor(cutree(hclust_ward, k=6)) ``` ::: ## Step 2: Append to the geospatial data ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} shan_sf_cluster <- cbind(shan_sf, as.matrix(groups)) %>% rename('CLUSTER'='as.matrix.groups.') %>% select(-c(3:4, 7:9)) %>% rename(TS = TS.x) ``` ::: ### Step 3: The Dendrogram ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} plot(hclust_ward, cex=0.6) rect.hclust(hclust_ward, k=6, border=2.5) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](In-class_Ex09_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Step 4: Cluster map ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} qtm(shan_sf_cluster, "CLUSTER") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](In-class_Ex09_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: ## 3.0 Spatially Constrained Clustering: SKATER method ::: panel-tabset ## Step 1: Computing nearest neighbours ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} shan.nb <- poly2nb(shan_sf) summary(shan.nb) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Neighbour list object: Number of regions: 55 Number of nonzero links: 264 Percentage nonzero weights: 8.727273 Average number of links: 4.8 Link number distribution: 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9 5 9 7 21 4 3 5 1 5 least connected regions: 3 5 7 9 47 with 2 links 1 most connected region: 8 with 9 links ``` ::: ::: ## Step 2: Visualising the neighbours ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} plot(st_geometry(shan_sf), border=grey(.5)) pts <- st_coordinates(st_centroid(shan_sf)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: st_centroid assumes attributes are constant over geometries ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} plot(shan.nb, pts, col="blue", add=TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](In-class_Ex09_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Step 3: Computing min spanning tree ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Calculating edge cost lcosts <-nbcosts(shan.nb, shan_ict) # Incorporating these costs into a weights object shan.w <- nb2listw(shan.nb, lcosts, style = "B") summary(shan.w) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Characteristics of weights list object: Neighbour list object: Number of regions: 55 Number of nonzero links: 264 Percentage nonzero weights: 8.727273 Average number of links: 4.8 Link number distribution: 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9 5 9 7 21 4 3 5 1 5 least connected regions: 3 5 7 9 47 with 2 links 1 most connected region: 8 with 9 links Weights style: B Weights constants summary: n nn S0 S1 S2 B 55 3025 76267.65 58260785 522016004 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Computing MST shan.mst <- mstree(shan.w) # Visualising MST plot(st_geometry(shan_sf), border=gray(.5)) plot.mst(shan.mst, pts, col="blue", cex.lab=0.7, cex.circles=0.005, add=TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](In-class_Ex09_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: ## 4.0 Computing spatially constrained clusters using SKATER method ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} skater.clust6 <- skater(edges = shan.mst[,1:2], data = shan_ict, method = "euclidean", ncuts = 5) plot(st_geometry(shan_sf), border=gray(.5)) plot(skater.clust6, pts, cex.lab=.7, groups.colors=c("red", "green", "blue", "brown", "pink"), cex.circles=0.005, add=TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning in segments(coords[id1, 1], coords[id1, 2], coords[id2, 1], coords[id2, : "add" is not a graphical parameter Warning in segments(coords[id1, 1], coords[id1, 2], coords[id2, 1], coords[id2, : "add" is not a graphical parameter Warning in segments(coords[id1, 1], coords[id1, 2], coords[id2, 1], coords[id2, : "add" is not a graphical parameter Warning in segments(coords[id1, 1], coords[id1, 2], coords[id2, 1], coords[id2, : "add" is not a graphical parameter ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](In-class_Ex09_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## 5.0 Visualising the clusters in choropleth map ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} groups_mat <- as.matrix(skater.clust6$groups) shan_sf_spatialcluster <- cbind(shan_sf_cluster, as.factor(groups_mat)) %>% rename('skater_CLUSTER'='as.factor.groups_mat.') qtm(shan_sf_spatialcluster, "skater_CLUSTER") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](In-class_Ex09_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## 5.0 Spatially Constrained Clustering: ClustGeo Method ::: panel-tabset ## Step 1: Computing spatial distance matrix ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} dist <- st_distance(shan_sf, shan_sf) distmat <- as.dist(dist) ``` ::: ## Step 2: The code ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} cr <- choicealpha(proxmat, distmat, range.alpha = seq(0, 1, 0.1), K=6, graph = TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](In-class_Ex09_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-13-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](In-class_Ex09_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-13-2.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Step 3: Saving clustGeo output ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} clustG <- hclustgeo(proxmat, distmat, alpha = 0.2) groups <- as.factor(cutree(clustG, k=6)) shan_sf_clustGeo <- cbind(shan_sf, as.matrix(groups)) %>% rename('clustGeo' = 'as.matrix.groups.') ``` ::: ::: ## 6.0 Visualising the clustGeo map ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} qtm(shan_sf_clustGeo, "clustGeo") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](In-class_Ex09_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## 7.0 Characterising the clusters ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ggparcoord(data = shan_sf_clustGeo, columns = c(17:21), scale = "globalminmax", alphaLines = 0.2, boxplot = TRUE, title = "Multiple Parallel Coordinates Plots of ICT Variables by Cluster") + facet_grid(~ clustGeo) + theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 30)) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](In-class_Ex09_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-16-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: callout-note Cluster 4 have a large variation for MPHONE_PR (long box plot) - Line = individual household (1 observation) - more lines = more observation We can even compare between groups, how each differs from each other (eg. Radio_PR in 1st cluster have lesser variation compared to 2nd cluster Radio_PR) If a lot of the line goes in parallel (eg. Cluster 4) then there is a lot of similarity :::
